entry.title: Over-Engineering thisÂ blog
entry.content:
Over the last few weeks Iâ€™ve spent an unreasonable amount of time and energy making unnecessary improvements to thisÂ blog.

Some of these improvementsÂ are:

  1. Adding keyboard shortcuts (type ? to find outÂ which).
  2. Implementing, then reimplementing, and then optimizing client side fuzzyÂ search.
  3. Using src-set to serve responsive images (Image-Process).
  4. Lazy loading images to make this site loadÂ faster.
  5. Compressing page files using brotli and also gzip (Precompress).
  6. Trying (and ultimately failing) to avoid a â€œwhite flashâ€ when dark mode is chosen and a new page loads (Github discussion).

Iâ€™m not really sure why I did it. It makes almost no difference to anyone but me. It felt a bitÂ compulsive.

I like tinkering, and itâ€™s nice to build something that will continue to work with no maintenance. I tell myself that over the next few years I will gain the benefits of these features even when Iâ€™ve forgotten I implementedÂ them.

Itâ€™s taught me a lot of JavaScript, which is a great language to be familiar with - itâ€™s everywhere. I would warmly encourage someone younger than myself to pursue interests for the sake of curiosity and fun. And there is a very high chance that even if no-one uses the shortcuts except me, my new javascript skills will come in useful somewhereÂ else.

But even if they do Iâ€™m not sure its a good enough reason - things should be built when they solve a present problem, not over-engineered for what-ifs and maybes. YAGNI. I wouldnâ€™t let myself do this in a professional capacity. There is a tension between being curious and beingÂ focussed.

Iâ€™m not really sure that I need to justify myself. Its a hobby, I wanted to do it, I enjoy tinkering with web technologies and learning newÂ things.

But also, I lost sleep over this - I stayed up too late, and let it put pressure on otherÂ things.

I know that being curious, and making room to play with interesting things, has been one of the most useful approaches to personal development and up-skilling myself. But there must be aÂ limit..

There is a tension between wasting my time and taking a risk, and it will take a few years before I know for sure if these efforts were worthwhile, orÂ not.

If itâ€™s not fun, donâ€™t doÂ it.

Successful business owners seem to be very good at leaving things alone once theyâ€™re â€œgood enoughâ€, and not being perfectionists. In fact, I think that being a perfectionist is antithetical to being an entrepreneur. I am not a perfectionist, Iâ€™m just really curious and have a big appetite forÂ learning.

But this â€œappetite for learningâ€ stops me from focussing. I let myself become distracted by adding new features to this blog, when instead I should zoom out a bit and think about working towards a more substantial and meaningful goal, to the exclusion of more minorÂ goals.

I think that good entrepreneurs are very focussed, to a fault. I am not that focussed. I am too distracted byÂ life.

Itâ€™s a balancing act, there is a tension between being emotionally and physically present with my family and friends, and ignoring as many things as possible so that I can focus on doing something meaningful that is necessarilyÂ hard.

entry.title: Notes From An Interview With GeoffreyÂ Hinton
entry.content:
1. Read the literature, but donâ€™t read too much ofÂ it.

  2. Trust your intuitions, because if you donâ€™t trust them then thereâ€™s noÂ point

  3. â€˜This person is either drunk or stupidâ€˜ - feedback on one of his papers that went on to becomeÂ significant

  4. For creative researchers; read a bit of the literature and notice something that you think everybody is doing wrong. (I guess GH is contrarian in thisÂ sense)

  5. Look for a problem that doesnâ€™t feel right. Then figure out how to do itÂ right.

  6. When people tell you that your (contrarian) approach is just no good, just keep atÂ it.

  7. Either your intuitions are good or theyâ€™re not. If they are good then you should follow them and you will eventually be successful. If they are bad then it doesnâ€™t matter what youÂ do.

  8. You might as well trust yourÂ intuitions.

  9. When you try to replicate a published paper you discover all the little tricks needed to make itÂ work.

  10. Never stopÂ programming.

  11. If you give a student something to do and they are a bad student then theyâ€™ll come back and say it didnâ€™t work. Theyâ€™ll say this because of some little decision they made which they didnâ€™t realise was crucial. But if you give it to a good student, you can give them anything and they will come back and say itÂ works

  12. Read enough so that you start developing intuitions, and then trust your intuitions and go for it! - Donâ€™t be too worried if everybody else says itsÂ nonsense.

  13. If you think itâ€™s a really good idea, and others tell you its complete nonsense, then you know you are really ontoÂ something!

    One example of this is when Ramford and I first came up with variational methods, I sent a mail explaining it to a former student, who showed it to his colleagues. He told me that they said â€˜Either this guy is drunk or he is just stupidâ€™. They really really thought is wasÂ nonsense.

    Maybe that is partly because of how i explained it - I explained it in intuitive terms, but when you have what you think is a good idea and other people think it is complete rubbish, that is the sign of a really goodÂ idea.

  14. See if you can find an advisor who has beliefs similar to your own, because if you work on stuff that your adviser feels deeply about, then youâ€™ll get a lot of good advice and time fromÂ them.

  15. Read enough so that you can trust yourÂ intuitions

entry.title: Photographs
Mental Models I Used ToÂ Use
entry.content:
The rules1 and mental models that helped me succeed in one season or phase of life may not be the best for the nextÂ phase.

Here is a list of a few mental models I remember being concious of in previous years. Probably Iâ€™ve already forgottenÂ some.

  1. Always ask â€œwhyâ€¦â€. Be obsessive about this. Itâ€™s going to make things harder for a while before things get easier. Youâ€™ll find difficult answers that you otherwise wouldnâ€™t. If youâ€™re only concerned with the present then its true that ignorance is bliss, but otherwise itâ€™s aÂ liability.

  2. â€œWhat ifâ€¦â€ is another good question to ask aÂ lot.

  3. Adapt to the situation, donâ€™t make it adapt to you if you have any choice. Be kind of like water, going around things and through the gaps. Look for the edges and the gaps, the parts that arenâ€™t wellÂ known.

  4. Let people talk as much as they want to. Shut up and listen. If they mean you harm or donâ€™t respect you then itâ€™ll become more obvious the more they keep talking. If they mean you well or theyâ€™re saying something useful, you will benefit more from letting them talkÂ more.

  5. Inversion - it can be hard to know if you should do something, but how would you feel if you didnâ€™t do it, or if it didnâ€™tÂ happen?

  6. Regrets are inevitable, everyone has them. Same as making mistakes. Let your regrets be for things that you did do, and not what you didnâ€™tÂ do.

  7. If you are willing to try something, fail at it, and still be glad that you tried, then you should almost definitely do it. Commit to it and enjoy the experience! Donâ€™t be scared, or at least, be scared and optimistic and happy2.

  8. There is beauty and luxury in being in such a bad spot that you are backed into a corner with seemingly no way out. Things become black and white, instead of shades of gray, and that will make priorities and options much clearer. You are likely to work very efficiently and effectively in this scenario, and you will learn important things aboutÂ yourself.

    Now that Iâ€™m older and I have responsibilities, I canâ€™t ever let things become so bad that a situation becomes black and white. I have to navigate a world of grays. If they do become black and white, Iâ€™ll already have a long list ofÂ failings.

    When I was younger, things were more fragile. My resources were smaller and things could quickly flip from good to bad. Enjoy the few benefits that a situation like that gives, because (hopefully) once its gone its gone forÂ good.

  9. The best way to solve a problem is to prevent it from occurring in the first place. Succeeding at this will bring its ownÂ challenges.

  10. Take responsibility for things you are not responsible for, kind of. Do it deliberately and for your own benefit, but donâ€™t forget that you are only pretending that itâ€™s yourÂ responsibility.

    If you do this, you will force yourself to understand a situation more deeply and from other peoples perspectives. This will let you learn faster and help you in future. Keep this at arms length though - itâ€™s make-believe and you need to be able to switch it on and off. Itâ€™s a toy for you to play with. This seems to be what â€œextreme responsibilityâ€Â is.

I think its important to have mental models that youâ€™re comfortable with, because it lets you make decisions quickly and consistently. But understand that the map is not the territory, and these are just tools in aÂ toolbox.

entry.title: Whatâ€™s So Different AboutÂ Now
entry.content:
I think we are less aware of our ignorance than previous generations. It is easy to implicitly assume that all useful information is available to us, and that we are therefore more informed than we reallyÂ are.

I think this is because the internet has made information more accessible and global air travel have made the world feelÂ smaller.

Whilst an individual would hopefully never pretend to know everything, I think its easy to assume that the right information exists and is being used by the people to whom it isÂ relevant.

But the accessibility of all information has put us in a situation similar to information scarcity. We still need to actively search for the information we want, because the information that comes to us easily or for free is not equal to what we find when we applyÂ effort.

I can easily have so many short pieces of news or information that I am always slightly overwhelmed. The pace of modern communications encourages me to never slow down enough to form my own questions or frame my own arguments. I can always find an answer to my questions, but when was the last time I checked that whoever gave it to me wasnâ€™t going to profit fromÂ it?

entry.title: Predicting the Future using Human Nature andÂ Technology
entry.content:
Predicting the future sounds like a tough problem, but we try to do it all the time without realisingÂ it.

We predict the future when we think about how risky or scary something is, or when we think about whatâ€™s really going to change because of an announcement or press release. We try to predict the future when weâ€™re at the supermarket checkouts and we try to pick the queue that will move the fastest. I always seem to pick the wrongÂ one.

There must be a million ways of trying to predicting the future but all the good ones are models which reduce complexity and emphasise key considerations. One of them could be comparing the influence of human nature and technology on the outcome, and then comparing the event to whatâ€™s happenedÂ before.

Human nature doesnâ€™t change, so if something is driven by fear or greed then it probably doesnâ€™t matter what century it occurs in. Technology is change, and if something is enabled or prevented due to technological progress then the date isÂ important.

What is driving the scenario? Is it human nature or technology? Supermarket checkouts are mostly manual and require a couple of adults to work together, so human nature has a much bigger role on efficiency than tech. Young men will stack and pack quickly, old women will be the opposite. What types of shopping bags they have, or how they pay, or even how many items theyâ€™re buying, are probably not going to lead you to the rightÂ decision.

The same probably works for getting through airportÂ security.

entry.title: Financial Doom AndÂ Gloom
entry.content:
Financial crises seem to happen fairly regularly so they shouldnâ€™t be unexpected. But no-one seems particularly concerned about our current financial system, at the moment our attention is controlled by otherÂ threats.

Iâ€™m concerned that a lot of money has been injected into the money supply but we havenâ€™t seen any inflation. And I am concerned that the price of stocks is no longer related to the value created by the company but instead by macroÂ economics.

Itâ€™s a terrible time to be a value investor. This should be an alarming statement. Value investing should always be a decent way to make money unless markets are broken. If the price of something doesnâ€™t represent its value then a correction isÂ inevitable.

Interest rates are really low at the moment so if you have spare money and you want to make it work for you then where do you put it? Not into a bank account, because interest rates are low1, and not into government debt, because the yield is so low. It has to be stocks if you want the value of your investments to increaseÂ meaningfully.

But everyone is doing this which drives the price up, and because their price is increasing they increase evenÂ further.

I think that the main reason for concern is super low interest rates and massive increases in the money supply, but there are a couple of other factors that are alsoÂ contributing.

Itâ€™s easier than ever for retail investors to participate in the stock market, and this seems like a good idea. Democratization. However if retail investors have influence to effect prices, and they themselves can be manipulated or influenced regarding what or when they buy or sell, then that is likely a new kind of threat to financial stability. Weâ€™ve never seen social media combined with quick, cheap investment services for amateursÂ before.

Index funds are also more popular than ever2 - the efficacy of index investing relative to traditional funds that use stock pickers is very high over medium or long time horizons because index funds are much cheaper. But if index funds become too large then they end up influencing the market in predictable and rigidÂ ways.

Index funds cannot choose what they buy or how much they buy - they just track the index. If a companyâ€™s stock crosses certain thresholds, their stock has to be bought or sold. It seems like its possible to create feedback loops where funds have to buy more of a rising stock, which increases its scarcity and price, which then requires index funds to purchase more of the sameÂ stock.

The amount of euros in existence in 2019 was 90% more than in 2010.3 But inflation between 2010 and 2020 is 13%.4 Why isÂ that?

If the price of something doesnâ€™t represent its value, then a correction isÂ inevitable.

entry.title: Why I Want To WriteÂ Regularly
entry.content:
Iâ€™ve started writing more frequently. I want to do this because I often have thoughts which Iâ€™d like to explore and develop further but rarely do. Writing forces me to organise my thoughts and look at how substantial they really are, orÂ arenâ€™t.

There is truth in the saying that â€œto know a thing you need to be able to teach itâ€ 1 , and writing well has several similarities to teaching. Can I really copy a collection of thoughts from my head toÂ yours?

Powerful ideas are resilient and have many consequences. The older I get the more I believe that ideas matter2. They have so many subtle consequences. They are the first dominos.

I donâ€™t expect writing regularly to become a permanent habit - it doesnâ€™t need to be. But I do want to focus on it for awhile so that I become significantly better. Itâ€™s a skill that has too many benefits to beÂ ignored.

The blogs I remember most are focussed and unapologetic about their priorities. Most of them have a lot of text and do not focus on design. They make it easy to read content and donâ€™t spend time or attention on header images orÂ styling.

Before I redesigned this blog I had default settings that asked me to supply an image for each post, and for a summary, and a suggested tweet. None of it was necessary and whilst they all tried to make the blog better they ended up making it harder to write. These peripheral features added complexity and distracted from the mainÂ thing.

Theyâ€™re are still there if I want to use them but they are not set up to be used by default anymore. Theyâ€™ve been moved to the background and if I forget they exist then thatâ€™s OK - it just shows they werenâ€™t as important in practice as I thought they would be. entry.title: Using RSS
entry.content:
Updated: 10 FebÂ 2021

I found a blog post which is surprisingly similar to my thoughts on RSS feeds, but better presented and thought through. The post mentions the idea that â€œRSS is about capturing the long tail of blogs that donâ€™t post frequentlyâ€ 1.

This idea crystalised why I was so glad Iâ€™d started using RSS feeds again. If readers use RSS, then authors donâ€™t need to concern themselves with attention. This removes pressure on the author to post frequently and lets them focus on quality over quantity. News feeds and ad supported platforms have fundamentally different mechanics andÂ incentives.

With RSS I can let good quality content come to me, on its own schedule. I donâ€™t need to remember to look for it, and the authors donâ€™t need to remind me that theyÂ exist.

GoogleÂ Reader

RSS is a very effective way of having good quality information come to you. Back in 2008, I used to use Google Reader to subscribe to RSS feeds. I was an aspiring photographer back then and I remember being subscribed to around 80 blogs. Each day Iâ€™d read articles from whoever had posted something new, without needing to visit their websites or remember who they are or that Iâ€™d subscribed to their blog. The authors didnâ€™t need to optimize their output according to an opaque and changing algorithm either - they didnâ€™t need to optimize article length, tags, post frequency, image inclusion or linked content. They could write how they wanted to, which I suspect leads to higher qualityÂ content.

SocialÂ Media

A few years later Google Reader was closed down, presumably because using RSS didnâ€™t fit with Googles advertising model. I was unaware of it at the time but I imagine it sent shockwaves through blogging communities and probably upended many businesses. I mostly stopped readingÂ blogs.

Facebook was growing fast, Instagram felt new and exciting, and content was moving onto â€˜platformsâ€™, or into walled gardens. And as they kept on growing the average quality of the contentÂ decreased.

Twitter is like this now I think. There are some real diamonds to be found from time to time, but thereâ€™s a lot of mud too. Mostly its just mud, but the occasional diamond can have outsizedÂ benefits.

RSS isnâ€™t like this. I choose the contents of my â€˜news feedâ€™, and each article can be much longer than a Tweet, or a caption to a photo, or a status update. Itâ€™s hard to write well and to create an interesting or useful blog post, and that makes it harder to dilute quality with entertaining distractions. I have complete control about what content I see, and I can change it whenever I want. The process is designed aroundÂ me.

Reeder5

I used netNewsWire for a few weeks, but it couldnâ€™t sync between my laptop and phone, so I bought Reeder 5. Itâ€™s got a few unusual design patterns, but it works well and has all the features I want. Iâ€™ve been unsubscribing from email newsletters and subscribing to the RSS feedÂ instead.

It keeps my inbox quieter, and it feels good to have a â€˜separation of concernsâ€™. It makes it easier to read interesting content without beingÂ distracted.

entry.title: Why Talk AboutÂ Jesus?
entry.content:
Start withÂ happiness

It seems to me that I am much happier as a Christian than I would be if I werenâ€™t. By â€œbeing a Christianâ€ I mean following Jesus - trying my best to act, think and speak like he wantâ€™s me to because Iâ€™m grateful that he did what I believe he did. I believe he died for my sins and is now alive, having been miraculously resurrected by his father1 (who is now my fatherÂ too).

Itâ€™s not just an intellectual exercise. I believe that Jesus is alive because I seem to have experienced his companionship and intervention in my day-to-day life. This is unusual, mind boggling, and makes things significantly more complicated than if I thought he were dead. Nonetheless it seems to beÂ true.

Itâ€™s not like I see supernatural intervention every day or anything, but there have been various times - too many to discard - when my prayers have been answered in practical ways (Iâ€™ll leave out the intangible for now) that have surprised me and given me a lot of respect for the risen Jesus doing what its said heâ€™d do in theÂ bible.

ObviousÂ answers

There was this time I was in Yemen trying to get back to my room across town, at night and during a storm. I was lost and couldnâ€™t read Arabic to understand which bus to get. So I prayed, and two buses later I got off at the rightÂ stop.

Another example, I was getting a haircut in Liverpool Street Station in London, and as I was sitting in the chair someone took my work bag. When I came to pay, I realised my laptop and wallet hadÂ gone.

Trying to find a stolen bag in central London feels ridiculous. Even so, I spent a few hours wondering around the alleys and parks looking for it, and I resigned myself to some awkward conversations and using most of my next salary to replace the stolenÂ computer.

To my surprise, my parents-in-law prayed about it and were really confident it would come back to me, which seemed super unlikely. A few days later I received a call from an office worker in the Gherkin building - my bag was under his desk and he wanted to know if Iâ€™d like to collect it. I guess Iâ€™ll try not to make the same mistakeÂ twice.

The other example I tend to remember happened not long after Iâ€™d first moved to Vienna. I was feeling lonely and isolated and I was wondering how on earth I was going to find some sort of normal that was healthy and sustainable. Try as I might, I wasnâ€™t enjoying things at all and was feeling stressed and overwhelmed. I remember walking up this steep hill in the 18th district towards my office, and repeatedly praying this really simple prayer â€˜God, please help, please help, please help..â€™. It was that simple because I couldnâ€™t think of anything more useful toÂ say.

Nothing dramatic happened that day, or even that week as far as I can remember. But when I look back, it was a turning point when things started getting better instead ofÂ worse.

I suppose you can call this last example an intangible answer to prayer. Maybe it is, but I think anyone whose grappled with overwhelming loneliness or panic would say that the emotions become all too tangible at times. Being in a different emotional state seemed to make a tangible difference to just about every area of life. Eating, productivity at work, relationships with friends and colleagues,Â etc.

This is only the beginning of why I think Jesus is alive and why I think Christianity is a real and living faith. Itâ€™s not primarily a tradition, a worldview or a set of rules andÂ ideals.

Christianity is a relationship with Jesus. He did lots of amazing things that have let me have a very practical relationship with him. Itâ€™s an almost unbelievable premise from which to live a life. It has so many implications. And it holds up to scrutiny and my experiences bear itÂ out.

Why writeÂ this?

Despite Jesusâ€™ incredible works and their implications, modern Christianity seems to be in a really confused and ineffective state. Ideas and thoughts about Christianity-the-faith have become mixed up with cultural christianity, or christian politics and traditions. These are each different things, and unless we distinguish between them with the words we use, we are going to find it hard to think and communicateÂ clearly.

I suspect that we are in a negative cycle of imprecise thinking leading to imprecise articulation, which leads to further impreciseÂ thinking.

Unless we can talk and think about one thing at a time, atomically2 if necessary, we take on the additional risks of reaching the wrong conclusions personally, or arguing with others due to misunderstandings rather than actualÂ disagreement.

We should try to create a more precise vocabulary to navigate our Christian lives, so that we can think clearly about the experiences and questions weÂ have.

Imprecise thinking is frustrating, and conversations are less effective when thereâ€™s an increased risk of disagreement or misunderstanding what someone else means. entry.title: Product-LedÂ Growth
entry.content:
Part 1: Design yourÂ strategy

Chapter 1: Why is product-led growth of risingÂ importance?

  1. Product-Led Growth is a go-to-market (GTM) strategy that relies on using your product as the main vehicle to acquire, activate and retainÂ customers.
  2. Product-Led Growth (PLG) means that every team influences the product:
    • Marketing - how can our products generate a demandÂ fly-wheel?
    • Sales - how can we use the product to qualify our prospects forÂ us?
    • Customer Success - how can we create a product that helps customers become successful beyond ourÂ dreams?
  3. By having every team focussed on the product, you create a culture that is built around enduring customerÂ value
  4. By leading with the product throughout the org, PL companies get
    • shorter salesÂ cycles
    • lower Customer Acquisition CostsÂ (CACs)
    • higher Revenue Per Employee (RPE)
  5. A GTM strategy is an action plan that specifies how a company will reach target customers and achieve a competitiveÂ advantage
  6. In order to select a GTM, you first need to understand:
    • marketÂ conditions
    • competitiveÂ positioning
    • idealÂ customer
    • productÂ offering
  7. Knowing these elements will help you choose the correct GTM that will acquire, retain and grow you customer base in the most capital-efficientÂ way

Sales-Led Go-To-MarketÂ Strategies

Profit Centers: Sales, Marketing, CustomerÂ Success

Cost Centers: Engineering,Â Product

Advantages:

  • Annual Contract Value (ACV) can be veryÂ high
  • Enterprise first solutions that are very complex and therefore need a high-touch salesÂ model
  • If the Total Addressable Market (TAM) is very small, because your market is super niche, you can quite easily talk to almost all market participants. (PLG is built for largeÂ TAMs)
  • Itâ€™s great for new categories of product where education is required, because you need to change how people approach a problem. This takes time and requiresÂ education.

This is turn requires that you understand your customers pain points, objections, core problems. If you jump to quickly a PLG GTM strategy then you risk a high church rate because you havenâ€™t understood or educated your customers wellÂ enough.

Disadvantages:

  • Sales cycles are veryÂ long
  • The Life Time Value (LTV) must be high enough to recoup the investment in CAC. This often requires charging the customer a premium. This premium price isnâ€™t because the product is amazing, or more valuable to the customer, but because the customer acquisition model is moreÂ expensive.
  • If you use a Sales-Led GTM, you need to watch out for competitors who can sell more efficiently, or have a more efficient Customer Acquisition Model. They can steal your market share by offering the same product with at a lowerÂ price.
  • Customer Acquisition methods are super leaky. Most marketing-qualified leads (MQLs) never result in a closed deal, this is partly because:
    • it encourages markets to gate content in order to hit their MQLÂ goals
    • it focusses on content consumption as a leading indicator of intent. (but reading a white-paper or brochure doesnâ€™t mean Iâ€™m going to buy theÂ thing).
    • the entire process rewards creating friction in the buyingÂ process
  • Consequently, there is often a disconnect between marketing andÂ sales

Product-Led Go-To-MarketÂ Strategies

  • Switching from Sales-Led GTM to Product-Led GTM creates a defensiveÂ moat
  • A product led marketing team asks â€œHow can we use the product to qualify our prospects forÂ us?â€
  • A product led customer success team asks â€œHow can we create a product that helps customers be successful without ourÂ help?â€
  • A product-led engineering team asks â€œHow can we create a product with a quickÂ time-to-value?â€
  • Growth is much faster, because:
    • you need fewer resources toÂ scale,
    • the top of the customer funnel is muchÂ wider.
    • CAC is muchÂ lower
    • Higher RPE (revenue perÂ employee)
    • User experience isÂ better

Chapter 2 - Free, Freemium orÂ Demo

  1. Use the MOAT framework to pick the right GTMÂ strategy:

    • Market Strategy - Dominant? Disruptive?Â Differentiated?
    • Ocean Conditions - Blue orÂ Red?
    • Audience - Do you have a top-down or bottom-up marketingÂ strategy?
    • Time to Value - How much time do you need for a customer to experience theÂ value?

  2. Dominant - Do it better than the competition and charge a lowerÂ price

    • Is your TAM bigÂ enough?
    • Does your product solve a specific job significantly better and at lower cost than anyone else on theÂ market?
    • Can the user realize significant ongoing value quickly with little or noÂ help?
    • Do you want to be the undisputed marketÂ leader?
  3. Differentiated - Pick and win a fight against an industry giant
    • Main line of defense against the giant isÂ specialization
    • Focus on an underservedÂ niche
    • Do a specific job better than the competition but charge significantlyÂ more
    • This is not a one-size-fits-allÂ model.
    • Free trials and demos work wellÂ here.
    • Because its specialized, combining freemium with quick time-to-value isÂ difficult
    • Main competitive advantage is how you solve your customersÂ problems
    • Does your market have underservedÂ customers?
    • Is the TAM bigÂ enough?
    • is the ACV highÂ enough?
    • Could prospects experience a Magic Moment during a freeÂ trial?
  4. Disruptive - Charge less for an inferior product (e.g. Canva, Google docs)
    • Build a simpler product that solves a specific pain point, and because its simpler, its faster, you can charge less, and its more appropriate to some over-served or priced-outÂ customers
    • Itâ€™s a scaled-downÂ product
    • Costs must beÂ low
    • Product must be easy toÂ use
    • Is TAM largeÂ enough?
    • Can on-boarding be completelyÂ self-service?
    • Freemium modelÂ thrives

Chapter 3 - Red-Ocean or Blue-OceanÂ markets?

Red-ocean companies try to outperform their rivals in order to grab a larger share of the existing market. As the market gets crowded, opportunity for profit and growth reduces. Products become commodities. Cut-throat competition turns the watersÂ red.

Blue-ocean companies access untapped market space and create demand. They have opportunity for highly profitable growth. Competition is irrelevant. Create and capture newÂ demand.

Some markets will be red-ocean, but a particular niche within it will be blueÂ ocean.

Blue Oceans require educating the customer to create the demand. This is high-touch, and often a PL GTM strategy isnâ€™t going to work. It needs to be sales-led in order to educate the customer enough. But if Time-To-Value (TTV) is short then PLG could beÂ great.

Red Oceans need big wide funnels in order to compete, and PL GTM strategies work great. Theyâ€™re defensible, keep costs low and make sales cyclesÂ short.

Chapter 4 - Top-Down or Bottom-Up sellingÂ strategy?

  1. PLG works forÂ bottom-up.
  2. High touch sales-led strategies work for Top-Down enterprise sales strategies, where the product is super complex and the sales cyccle is veryÂ long.

Top-Down (Sales team is the growthÂ engine):

  • High ACV
  • AdditionalÂ Services
  • Lower customerÂ churn
  • Poor revenueÂ distribution
  • High CAC
  • Long salesÂ cycles
  • Free Trial sometimesÂ works

Bottom-Up (Product is the growthÂ engine):

  • WiderÂ top-of-funnel
  • Low CAC
  • Predictable salesÂ figures
  • RevenueÂ diversity
  • ScalableÂ fast
  • Small contractsÂ only
  • non-payingÂ customers
  • expertiseÂ shortage
  • upfront investment as non-paying customers drainÂ resources
  • Freemium
  • Free-Trial

Chapter 5 -Â Time-to-Value

  1. How much time until you deliver on your promise toÂ prospects?
  2. How much time until the product sellsÂ itself?
  3. PL GTM strategies require fastÂ time-to-value.
  4. Rank your uses across 2 dimensions and group into 4 quadrants. The dimensions are Ability (low - high) and Motivation (low - high)
    1. Low Motivation - Low Ability = MissionÂ Impossible
    2. High Motivation - Low Ability =Â Rookie
    3. Low Motivation - High Ability =Â Veteran
    4. High Motivation - High Ability =Â Spoiled
  5. Figure out your top two quadrants. Unless all your users are Spoiled, you need to decreaseÂ Time-To-Value.

Questions:

  • How motivated are yourÂ users?
  • Is your product easy for your target audience toÂ use?
  • Can users experience the core value (magic moment?) withoutÂ hand-holding?

Part 2 - Build YourÂ Foundation

Chapter 7 - Build a product-ledÂ foundation

A positive feedbackÂ loop:

  1. Understand yourÂ value
  2. CommunicateÂ it
  3. Deliver on yourÂ promise
  4. Repeat

Chapter 8 - Understand yourÂ value

If youâ€™re selling live-chat software, youâ€™re not really selling live-chat software, you are selling a new and better way to acquireÂ customers.

You are selling the outcome, the result, theÂ why.

Pain makes us want to change so that we can avoid or prevent the painÂ altogether.

Pain is productÂ agnostic.

There are three reasons why people buy aÂ product:

  1. Functional Outcome - the core task that needs to getÂ done.
  2. Emotional Outcome - how a customer wants to feel or avoid feeling as a result of the functionalÂ outcome.
  3. Social Outcome - how a customer wants to be perceived by others by using yourÂ product.

In every software, there are usage patterns that point towards to core outcomes that are most important toÂ customers.

One of the biggest differences between sales-led and product-led companies is that SL companies monitor usage patters to see if users are accomplishing meaningful outcomes. These outcomes are referred to as value-metrics.

A value-metric is the way you measure value exchange in your product. They are the linchpin to successful execution of a product-led GTM strategy because you are aligning your revenue model directly with your customer acquisition model. Because your value metrics play a vital role in how you price your product, set up your monitoring, and build yourÂ team.

Value metrics couldÂ be:

  • for Vimeo, number of videos uploaded by theÂ user.
  • for Slack, number of messages sent by theÂ user
  • for PayPal, amount of revenue generated by the userÂ (processed?)

There are functional and outcome based value metrics. Functional value metrics are â€œper userâ€ or â€œper 100 videosâ€. Pricing scales around functions of usage. Outcome based value metrics charge based on the outcome, e.g. how many views a video received, or how much money a customer made when using your payment processÂ method.

Many SaaS companies rely on feature differentiation as a way to justify higher prices, but this produces higherÂ churn.

Value metrics outperform feature differentiation with upto 75% lessÂ churnâ€¦

Outcome based value metrics reduce church by an additional 40%.Â Apparently.

  1. A good value metric is easy for a customer to understand. They need to immediately understand what theyâ€™re paying for and where they fit in your packing/pricing structure. If youâ€™re in an established market, it makes senses to look at what the competitionÂ charges.
  2. A good value metric is aligned with the value that the customer receives through the product. Consider the low-level components of your high-level outcome. E.g. what low level actions are necessary to get the end result? Sending lots of messages? Meeting lots of people? Finding lots ofÂ things?
  3. A good value metric grows with your customers usage of the valuable outcome. If customers get incredible value from the product, charge them more because the product is worth it. Also, if they arenâ€™t getting much value from the product, charge themÂ less.
  4. Donâ€™t do user based pricing if you want to get lots of users - its a conflict ofÂ interests.
  5. If youâ€™re small, you can try different pricing strategies and iterate toÂ success.

AskÂ yourself:

  1. What do my best customersÂ do?
  2. What do my best customers notÂ do?
  3. What features did my best customers try first when they wereÂ on-boarding?
  4. What are the similarities along my best customers that led toÂ success?
  5. For churned customers, what were the main differences between them and the best customers? Were they in the ideal audience? Why did they church? What did they do or not do that good customersÂ didnâ€™t?

entry.title: The MomÂ Test
entry.summary: My notes on “The Mom Test” by Rob Fitzpatrick
entry.content:
Itâ€™s called the Mom Test because it leads to questions that even your mom couldnâ€™t lie to youÂ about

Overview:

  1. Ask goodÂ questions
  2. Avoid badÂ data
  3. Keep itÂ casual
  4. Push for commitment andÂ advancement
  5. Frame the meetingÂ well
  6. Focus on the right, tight, customerÂ segment
  7. Prep well, take good notes, review yourÂ notes.

Chapter 1 - Opinions are worthless, you want objective facts about what happened in theÂ past

  1. Find out if people care about your idea by never mentioningÂ it.
  2. Forcing yourself not to mention your idea will force you to ask betterÂ questions
  3. Make sure your questions pass the mom test:
    • Talk about their lives, not your idea Ask about specifics in theÂ past,
    • not hypotheticals Spend most of your time listening, notÂ talking

Rule of thumb: Anything involving the future is an overly optimisticÂ lie

Chapter 2 - Avoid bad data - Compliments, Fluff, Hypotheticals,Â Ideas

You arenâ€™t allowed to tell them what their problem is, and they arenâ€™t allowed to tell you what toÂ build.

Chapter 3 - Ask the ImportantÂ Questions

You should be terrified of at least one of the questions you ask in eachÂ conversation

  1. Search out the scary questions youâ€™ve been unintentionally avoiding. Whatâ€™s the worst thing a prospect could say? Whatâ€™s the scariest question you couldÂ ask?
  2. A good way to find scary questions is to imagine that your company has failed and then to askÂ why.
  3. If you get an unexpected answer to one of your questions and it doesnâ€™t have any effect on what youâ€™re going to do, then was it really worth askingÂ it?
  4. General advice for hard things including asking hard questions - imagine you were delegating the task, what would you tel the person to do? Thatâ€™sÂ you.
  5. You can ask aboutÂ money.
  6. Love bad news - if you find out that your idea is fundamentally flawed youâ€™ve just saved a tonne of time and energy and money. Move on. Itâ€™s getting you closer to theÂ truth.
  7. Bad news isnâ€™t the result of an opinion. No one knows if your idea will work, only the market knows. Opinions donâ€™tÂ count.
  8. A lukewarm response to your idea can be a great conversation, because you realise that your idea isnâ€™t a great idea. Lukewarm means they donâ€™t care enough to buy the first (worst) version before itâ€™sÂ ready.
  9. Look before you zoom. Donâ€™t focus on details too soon, you need to understand the big pictureÂ first.
  10. You have product risk and customer risk:
    1. Product risk - can I build it and growÂ it?
    2. Customer risk - is there a big enough group of people who are going to buyÂ it?
  11. Pre-plan a list of the 3 most important questions (including a scary one) before every meeting or conversation. Be ready with these. They should change from week to week. As you get good quality answers to existing questions you can bring in newÂ questions.

Chapter 4 - Keep it casual, Structure: Problem -> Solution ->Â Sales

  1. Normally you would have 3 meetings with a client in order to make a big sale. This lets you do each stage really well without blurring the data:
    1. Identify your prospectâ€™sÂ problem
    2. Explain yourÂ solution
    3. Sell theÂ solution
  2. Identifying a problem doesnâ€™t have to be a meeting, keep it casual and you will get more honest feedback much faster. It works better as aÂ chat.
  3. It take 5 minutes (max) to identify if a problem exists and isÂ important

Give as little info as possible about your idea whilst still nudging the conversationÂ along

Chapter 5 - The currencies of conversation - Time, Reputation,Â Money

In early stage sales, the main goal is learning. Money is aÂ side-effect.

  1. If someone is willing to risk reputation, or spend time or money on your idea, then you can believe that theyâ€™reÂ interested.
  2. Hearing a compliment is still useful - it means theyâ€™re trying to get rid ofÂ you
  3. If its a bad meeting, push for a commitment of some kind. Ask them to spend time, reputation or money and youâ€™ll see what they reallyÂ think.
  4. If they arenâ€™t excited (not just interested, but in pain and excited for your solution) then you need to find that out ASAP. Itâ€™s still a good meeting if you can discoverÂ this.
  5. A lead isnâ€™t a real lead until youâ€™ve given them a concrete chance to rejectÂ you.
  6. Ask learning questions by using the Mom Test, then confirm by sellingÂ it.
  7. You need crazy customers:
    1. They have a painful and expensiveÂ problem
    2. They know they have a painful and expensiveÂ problem
    3. They have the money to pay you to solveÂ it
    4. They already have their own bad solution to this terrible problem, and yours is clearlyÂ better
  8. A crazy customer doesnâ€™t say â€œyeah thatâ€™s great, Iâ€™m really interested, let me know when its readyâ€. They say â€œAHHH THIS IS THE WORST PART OF MY LIFE AND I WILL PAY YOU RIGHT NOW TO FIX IT!â€
  9. A crazy customer will front you the money when all you have is a prototype made ofÂ duct-tape
  10. A crazy customer is the person reading you blog, searching for workarounds, when you havenâ€™t spent loads of marketing and leadÂ generation
  11. Keep a crazy customer close - theyâ€™ll stick with you when times areÂ tough.

Chapter 6 - Finding goodÂ conversations

eep having conversations until you stop hearing newÂ stuff

  1. If itâ€™s a topic you both care about, find an excuse. Youâ€™ll both enjoy the chat. You donâ€™t need to mention your idea if it breaks theÂ premise.
  2. Warm introductions are the ideal way to start a new conversation. 6 degrees of freedom in the world, so find someone who knows someone who knowsÂ someone..
  3. Cold calls - LinkedIn,Â maybe
  4. Serendipity - be prepared, beÂ bold
  5. Have a good excuse -Â hustle
  6. Landing pages so that googling the problems brings them toÂ you.
  7. Organise an event - bring the businesses together for an event. Youâ€™ll be considered an expert cos youâ€™re facilitatingÂ it.
  8. Become a subject matterÂ expert
  9. Speaking and teaching engagements - you get to have strong opinions, and youâ€™ll beÂ respected.

Vision -> Framing -> Weakness -> Pedestal ->Â Ask

Chapter 7 - Choosing youÂ customers

  1. Startups donâ€™t starve, they drown. In options, choices, ideas. You getÂ overwhelmed.
  2. Choose a good customer segment, focus on it, and donâ€™t getÂ distracted.
  3. In the beginning:
    1. Google - PhDÂ students
    2. PayPal -Â eBay
    3. Evernote - Moms with recipes,Â etc
  4. It will look obvious with hindsight, probably not so obvious before youâ€™ve figured it outÂ though.
  5. If you canâ€™t get a consistent answer to a question, maybe youâ€™re speaking to differentÂ segments
  6. If you arenâ€™t finding consistent problems and goals then you donâ€™t have a specific enough customer segment
    1. Within the group, which type of person would want it theÂ most?
    2. Would everyone within the group want to buy/use it? Or onlyÂ some?
    3. Why does the subset wantÂ it?
    4. Does everyone in the group have the sameÂ motivation?
    5. What other motivations areÂ there?
    6. Who else (outside the group) have theseÂ motivations?
  7. Go for Who-Where pairs of segments. â€œFinance professionals who runÂ marathonsâ€..
  8. You want customers who are reachable, profitable, and personallyÂ rewarding.

Good segments are usually â€œwho-whereâ€ pairs. If you donâ€™t know where to find your customers, keep slicing until you do. Make sure the segment is reachable, profitable, and personallyÂ rewarding

Chapter 8 - Getting the most from the conversations by prepping andÂ reviewing

  1. Prepare well
    1. Have you 3 big questions ready, including the scaryÂ ones
    2. Know who you are speakingÂ to
    3. Know what commitment and next-steps you want to pushÂ for
    4. Spend up to an hour writing down your best guesses about what you think they will say, what they care about and what they want. If you have a focussed segment, youâ€™ll only need to do thisÂ occasionally.
    5. Whilst prepping, if you come across a question which can be answered using the internet, use theÂ internet.
  2. Take good notes
    1. Ask if you can record theÂ audio
    2. Record emotions as well as words. Verbatim alone isnâ€™t always accurate 6 monthsÂ later
    3. Use shorthand for follow up, happy, angry, meh,Â etc
    4. Pains and obstacles are a lot more important if someone is embarrassed or angry when theyâ€™re talking aboutÂ them.
    5. Dig into the big emotions, find out whatâ€™s causing them, or why its a bigÂ deal
  3. Review your notes
    1. Meta - which questions went well orÂ not?
    2. What were the answers to the scaryÂ questions?
    3. How can you do better nextÂ time?
    4. What were the clear signals? What signals did youÂ miss?

entry.title: ObviouslyÂ Awesome
entry.content:
Intro

  1. In order to do better marketing, understand your value and differentiatorsÂ better
  2. Understand what makes a best-fitÂ customer
  3. Positioning is a fundamental input to every business tactic youÂ use
  4. If you fail at positioning, you fail at marketing andÂ sales
  5. Positioning is â€œconext settingâ€ forÂ products
  6. Customers need to be able to easily understand
    1. What your productÂ does
    2. Why it isÂ special
    3. Why it matters toÂ them
  7. If your prospects canâ€™t figure out what your product does quickly, they will invent a position for you. It might hide your key strengths or misunderstand yourÂ value.
  8. Find people to demo your product to, then ask them to describe it back to you. Do the same with existing customers. If theyâ€™re not saying the same thing then you have a positioningÂ problem.
  9. Products with strong positioning:
    1. Find the best kind ofÂ customer
    2. Make the valueÂ obvious
    3. SellÂ quickly

PartÂ 1

Positioning asÂ context

  1. Without positioning to guide us, we donâ€™t know how to understnad aÂ product
  2. Positioning lets us make assumptions about
    1. who a product isÂ for
    2. what its main featuresÂ are
    3. how much itÂ costs
  3. Without it we would be paralyzed by choice, and we wouldnt be able to make sense of all the products aroundÂ us.
  4. The context and purpose of a product from the founders/engineers perspective are often different to those of theÂ prospect
  5. Products can be positioned in multiple ways, and often the best positioning is not the defaultÂ positioning
  6. Bad positioning makes it harder for prospects to figure out if your product is worth thinkingÂ about.
  7. Positioning requires considering:
    1. Customers point of view - what problem/pain does itÂ solve
    2. The ways your product is uniquelyÂ different
    3. The characteristics of a potentialÂ customer
    4. The best market context to make your value uniquelyÂ obvious

Five (plus one) components of effectiveÂ positioning

  1. Competitive Alternatives - if you didnâ€™t exist, what would your customers use instead?
    1. Its what your prospects would use to do the task if your product didnâ€™t exist. It could be excel, or pen and paper. It could be nothing, (in which case maybe you product doesnâ€™t solve a real painÂ point.)
    2. You probably know a lot more about your market, and problem, and alternative solutions, than your prospects do. (â€œDoing nothingâ€ could be an opportunity, not a redÂ flag.)
    3. Its important to understand what customers will compare your product with, because this is how they will define â€œbetterâ€. Is it â€œeasierâ€ than a pen andÂ paper?
    4. Customers might never have purchased a solution like yoursÂ before.
  2. Unique Attributes - What do you have that alternative do not?
    1. Could be:
      1. Delivery Model (online vs offline, installed on-site vsÂ not)
      2. Business model (rental vsÂ purchase)
      3. Specific expertise (data scientist with financial and back-end web devÂ expertise)
  3. Value (and quantifiable objective proof) - What value do the attributes enable for customers?
    1. If unique attributes are your secret sauce, the value is why someone might care about your secretÂ sauce
    2. Fact based, provable, demonstrable, quantifiable, objective. Third party opinions areÂ relevant.
  4. Target market characteristics - Who cares a lot about that value?
    1. Focus on customers who are most likely to purchase quickly, wont ask for discounts, will tell their friends aboutÂ you.
    2. You should clearly identify who these areÂ and
    3. Identity what sets them apart from other groups of customers. Why are they uniquely likely to buy from you when others wouldnt or would take longer to consider and make aÂ purchase
  5. Market Category - What context makes your value obvious to the ideal customer?
    1. Declaring that your product exists in a certain market triggers a powerful set ofÂ assumptions
    2. make these assumptions help you, not hinderÂ you.
    3. When presented with your product, customers will try to use what they already know to figure out what your product is all about and why its special. You want them to be able to do this really quickly andÂ easily.
    4. Make these assumptions work for you, not against you. You wonâ€™t have to list every feature, because most of them will be assumed by the context of the marketÂ category.
    5. Get it right, and sales efforts (copy) wont be wasted battling those assumptions, but can instead build off of them to show secret sauce and value moreÂ obviously.
  6. (Bonus) Relevant Trends - what trends make your product relevant right now?
    1. Used carefully, trends can show prospoects why they should pay attention to your product right now. IncreasesÂ urgency.
    2. It can increase urgency, excitement, coolness,Â credibility
    3. but the trend must be directly relevant, practically and objectivelyÂ applicable.
    4. Blockchains, AI, ML are trends - they are relevant to multipleÂ markets.

Each of these components is relevant to theÂ others

entry.title: The 1-Page MarketingÂ Plan
entry.summary: My notes on “The 1-Page Marketing Plan” by Allan Dib
entry.content:
Introduction

Marketing has threeÂ phases

  • Before (prospect) - get people to know you and indicateÂ interest
  • During (lead) - get the to like you and buy from you for the firstÂ time
  • After (customer) - get them to trust you, buy from you regularly, andÂ refer
  • newÂ customers

Jargon free definition ofÂ marketing

Since April Iâ€™ve been able to work full time as a solo founder. Iâ€™ve challenged myself to build something useful enough that customers would want to pay for it and in the process of seeking that goal Iâ€™ve become a much better and more roundedÂ developer.

Iâ€™ve been working solo for about 7 months now, and in that time Iâ€™ve begun using test driven development, Iâ€™ve built non-trivial data driven web apps using Django, and Iâ€™ve learnt how to deploy and monitor those apps in production and make themÂ performant.

Iâ€™ve made two main apps; moneybar.nl and pippip.email, and Iâ€™ve learnt soÂ much.

Iâ€™m realising though, that I still have much to learn in other spheres. Being a great developer is deeply meaningful to me. Itâ€™s literally a bucket list item for me and I intend to be writing code as long as I live. But there is no point creating products if no one knows theyÂ exist.

This is where marketing and positioning comes in. Right now it feels like I know nothing about how to get users, or validate an idea, or position a product. These are all super necessary and superÂ unknown.

On a more meta level, Iâ€™m confronted with the lost benefits of working with co-founders, or of having friends doing similar things. I want to work faster and make progress more efficiently. I need to be part of aÂ community.

Working in isolation does have its advantages, though. Iâ€™m self-taught and self-directed, figuring out the contours of uncharted territory and creating my own personal map. In my mind, I have a deep and almost personal relationship with the coding abstractions and tools Iâ€™ve learnt to work with. Classes and functions, strings and floats, literally have (to me) their own textures, colors and weights when I think or dream aboutÂ them.

It feels like I can pick up these abstractions as if they were physical objects and turn them around to examine them. Place them next to each other and compare the differences. Run thought experiements. In my experience, this kind of relationship and affection simply doesnâ€™t happen when taking a class or following someone elses schedule. Itâ€™s satisying to feel ownership of a skill like this, and itâ€™s one of the primary reasons I consider coding to be similar to aÂ craft.

Having said all that, now that I realise I need to validate my product, position it, and figure out marketing, Iâ€™ve stopped writing code, put down my tools, and Iâ€™m going to learn marketing. Iâ€™ve bought some books. Maybe Iâ€™ll post some reviews hereÂ later.

In no particular order here is what I plan toÂ read:

entry.title: Coworking inÂ Dublin
entry.summary: A review of eight coworking spaces in Dublin
entry.content:
Last week I arrived in Dublin and had two days to find a coworking space. I ran around Dublin visiting as many asÂ possible.

Iâ€™m looking to rent a hotdesk, which means I donâ€™t have any storage space at the office and I donâ€™t have a particularÂ desk.

Below are my impressions of eight businesses offering either hot desks or dedicated desks, ranked in order of preference. Itâ€™s subjective. The going rate in Dublin seems to be â‚¬200 â€” â‚¬300 per month for a hot desk. Hours range from 9am - 7pm Monday - Friday, toÂ 24/7.

First place: DogpatchÂ Labs

Dogpatch offer a coworking space and access to a community of tech startups. They run regular networking and mentoring events and occupy 3 floors of a warehouse next to an old dock. The offices have a range of interiors styles. The middle level is fairly standard but pleasant open plan offices, the top floor is a flexible working space with event areas. The lower level is a series of vaults that each contain meeting rooms of various sizes. Thereâ€™s a lot going on and thereâ€™s a good buzz in theÂ air.

The range of interior spaces is a big plus for me and Iâ€™m looking forward to being able to switch up my working environment through the day. Thereâ€™s a couple of kitchen areas, and a table football and table-tennis table on the top level. Access is 6am - midnight, and a hot desk is â‚¬200 per month. A dedicated desk isÂ â‚¬400.

Dogpatch occupy less than a quarter of the warehouse building, the remainder of the space is used as a shopping mall and a museum. In my opinion Dogpatch is by far the best value and if youâ€™re working in tech itâ€™ll probably be your go-toÂ solution.

Second place: Studio9

These guys are great. The space is a lot smaller that Dogpatch, comprising only ~12 desks. Itâ€™s a basement, but donâ€™t let that put you off â€” its open plan and has large windows at either end. The space is well designed and uses a lot of light colours and textures, including wood on the walls and floors. There are also plenty of pot plants. These combine to give a bright and airy atmosphere that feels very natural andÂ bright.

There are alcoves down one side of the main room which serve as meeting rooms, and a garden and basic kitchen at the back. The owners want the space to foster a community, and I expect that this is achieved. There are no dedicated offices and no teams using multiple desks, everyone is an independentÂ worker.

The desks are large, and each has its own little wall to provide some privacy. â‚¬200 per month ongoing, or â‚¬250 for just one month. They offer a trial day forÂ free.

Third place: OfficeSuites

The building looks well run and appears clean and fresh with adequate resources. The building is an old Georgian tenement with high ceilings, cornicing and lots of natural light. The furnishings and decor lean towards corporate rather than something more interesting, but this works well to add a professional feel to the homely architecture. Access isÂ 24/7.

Thereâ€™s only two rooms for hotdesking, and most of the building is given to private offices. Thereâ€™s a garden with bike storage, meeting rooms and a quiet room for calls. Lockers are extra. They also offer a free day as aÂ trial.

â‚¬249 p/m for desk access 9am-7pm Monday -Â Friday

Fourth place: Element78

Friendly and well resourced, but very corporate. The architecture is corporate glass and steel. Theyâ€™re situated on the ground floor in a posh business district with large financials for neighbours. Itâ€™s too corporate for me, but if you wanted an impressive place to meet clients and a nice address, this could be it. There were about 15 hot-desks for rent, plus plenty of dedicated desks. Clients seemed to include mostly young tech companies and techÂ freelancers.

Iâ€™m hoping to find somewhere with more of a community, more inspiring architecture, and more character. I was offered a free day as aÂ trial.

â‚¬200 for the first month then â‚¬350Â p/m

Fifth place: Glandore

Glandore offer a relatively luxurious package with a corporate feel. They have a few buildings in Dublin and only the flagship has hotdesking space. Thereâ€™s a super looking restaurant and a large club room to relax in, but these are features that I donâ€™t need, and the rates arenâ€™t competitive if all you need is a desk and somewhere to take calls. Itâ€™s set up for teams and for impressing clients, and independent tech workers are probably better offÂ elsewhere.

â‚¬295Â p/m

Sixth place: Regus

Regus offer a polished on boarding experience and the friendly staff were quick to respond and generally helpful, but the office space was bland, grey and generic. The rooms I visited didnâ€™t have external windows and it reminded me of the rooms banks often put auditors in. If grey walls and tube lights are your thing then this is for you. 24/7 access, and meeting rooms equipped withÂ A/V.

â‚¬299.70Â p/m.

Seventh place: CoCreate

I visited the southern branch and thought the building was a bit shabby and needed a new layer of paint. I recognised the desks as some of the cheapest available from IKEA. The rooms were small and needed cleaning, and there was weird art on theÂ wall.

The thought of paying â‚¬200 a month to sit at a small wobbly desk put me off. The place was also almost deserted. Maybe their other branch is better, but this is not forÂ me.

â‚¬220Â p/m.

Last place: tCube

Last and least, tCube seems to be putting in zero effort. When I visited I saw two rooms that needed painting, disorganised furniture and abandoned bits of computers lying around. The kitchen isnâ€™t high spec and the meeting room isnâ€™t big enough. I was also given a speech about how great the wifi was - a prerequisite that was taken for granted everywhere else. At â‚¬300 p/m for a dedicated desk its easy to find better valueÂ elsewhere.

entry.title: CorporateÂ London
entry.summary: Reflections on 3 years living and working in London
entry.content:
2014 -Â 2017

Having made arrangements to leave London, it seems like a reasonable time to reflect on my timeÂ here.

London is a tough city to live in â€” itâ€™s big enough that a sub 1-hour commute is considered good, and itâ€™s super expensive. My stay in London has been defined by my quest to complete my graduate scheme and qualify as anÂ accountant.

When I first arrived I had no idea what London or working in a corporate would be like. I was coming from academia, and my motivation for moving to finance could be summed up in twoÂ points:

  1. Understand more about the 2008 financialÂ crisis
  2. Get paid more for using mostly the same skills (math) as inÂ engineering

I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything wrong with these motivations, but I should have been making a long term career planÂ instead.

When I started my job I was surprised at the 6 weeks of induction and hot-desking. Life as an auditor felt nomadic, as everyone would spend large amounts of time at clientâ€™s offices, and no-one has their own desk in our office. The only thing you really own is your knowledge and your network ofÂ relationships.

In 2014, I arrived with a high opinion of my employer and the view that I would be staying for several years. Having escaped the financial insecurity of short-term research grants, Iâ€™d moved back to my home country to contribute to the system that educated me. I was happy to have a regular job with a decent, predictableÂ salary.

A phrase that kept coming to mind back then was â€œaccountant factoryâ€. Our training materials were scripted and everything was a standardised process. We were being processed. Graduates in, corporate accountantsÂ out.

The company is huge and so are the efficiencies and barriers to competition that come with this. When I arrived I was impressed there were free biscuits, and it felt presumptuous to put a meeting in someones diary. Now I ignore any communications addressed to a mailingÂ list.

Accountant

The toughest experiences were related to the accountancy qualification. NaÃ¯vely I had believed that the qualification wouldnâ€™t be a big deal and I didnâ€™t give any thought to it when I applied â€” I just wanted to find out how banks worked. If there were some exams to be done then it would be fine, Iâ€™d already achieved a PhD and I would handleÂ it.

That turned out to be a mistake. A huge mistake. The alarm bells should have rung louder when I realised most of my graduate colleagues had only applied so that they could get the qualification (and were already intending to leave asap afterwards). Doing the pre-course work before college wasnâ€™t trivial. College - I was being sent to a classroom again. We were being taken out of the office, away from clients, and put in a classroom to prepare for theseÂ examsâ€¦

Starting a job that required becoming a chartered accountant, without considering the effort and time involved to qualify was dumb. Itâ€™s an oversight I find hard toÂ believe.

The disappointment and sadness at having to study again was profound. The teaching and assessment style was several steps behind what Iâ€™d become used to. Compared to the depth, autonomy and research-focus of a doctorate, writing cookie-cutter essays in time-pressured exams felt stupid. The exams were hard and I failed several of them, probably because of my low morale whilst revising. Retaking them required more weekends and annual leave being spent away from my family, camped-out in libraries andÂ offices.

This required much patience and generosity from Ritsya, who having not seen me for long periods during my doctorate expected us to have a more normal lifestyle when we came to London. I found it miserable to pause my social life and other interests whilst studying, and then I would try to rush back to them when I had the time, knowing that soon Iâ€™d have to pause themÂ again.

If I hadnâ€™t already studied in Vienna, this process of working and studying in London would have been exciting and felt valuable or special. Iâ€™d passed enough exams though to know that theyâ€™re never as important as theyâ€™re made out to be, and whatever it was that was missing from my life wasnâ€™t going to be found in anotherÂ qualification.

On the upside though, the ACA is the most practical qualification Iâ€™ve gained and has taught me many useful aspects of business and finance. Iâ€™m glad to finally see business not as some mysterious system but something attainable andÂ understandable.

Neighbourhood

Living in London has also required a lot of time on trains â€” my door to desk commute is about an hour each way, and Iâ€™ve never lived somewhere in London that hasnâ€™t felt transient. Weâ€™ve needed to live near a station and didnâ€™t want to commute more than an hour and thatâ€™s put us in neighbourhoods with other young professionals who also donâ€™t have long term plans (or financial ability) to stay in the city. Weâ€™re all looking to move on and move up as fast as possible. I want to leave London partly because there are so many people with the same attitudes and priorities as myÂ ownâ€¦

CorporateÂ Culture

Back in the office I spent the first few months figuring out how people were organised, how teams operated and how decisions were made. I think it took me about a year to feel like I understood how things really worked, and 1.5 years to feel like I could do all aspects of my job with certainty. There is a difference between how things are spoken about, and how things actuallyÂ happen.

My experience has been that performance is all that matters and behaviour is defined by self-interest. I donâ€™t think this is different from previous environments Iâ€™ve worked in â€” academia isnâ€™t any different1 and the construction industry certainly isnâ€™t. I wonder if the only way people can endure it is if theyâ€™ve not experienced anything else, or think it normal, or necessary. I find myself wishing we could be kinder to each other, and that we could create structures that incentivise mutualÂ support.

Corporate finance usually appears clean and well presented. Its people appear dependable and capable. The culture is sanitised and thereâ€™s a lot of pressure to conform - you can see it in the clothes and accessories we wear and the jokes we tell each other in theÂ canteen.

I came to see my office as a glass and steel cathedral. I read about the Middle East, and migrants arriving in Europe, and tower blocks burning, and felt reallyÂ disconnected.

Despite the high regard with which we hold ourselves, we donâ€™t ask each other how we can help. Maybe we are too busy, or feel powerless to help. Apparently we do not know how to help, despite our wealth, talents, education andÂ connections.

I remember watching a man leave the office one day and thought that if he gave his whole career and left his firm after decades of service, there would be nothing left to identify him after a few weeks. The work will always get done. Market forces will dictate how the business adapts and grows. The City rollsÂ on.

  1. Publications trump almost all other metrics, and the incentives to publish quantity over quality are such that risky or slow research is inexcusable. The metrics used to standardise success and allocate resources can be subverted just as well in academia as in any other industry. What management measures, the team prioritises.Â â†©

AutumnÂ 2016

entry.title: How to be an ambitious founder inÂ Europe
entry.summary: Creating something that matters is hard. Learn to leverage your time, you can never get it back. Being a successful founder is not impossible, it is always exciting.
entry.content:
Whilst at the Lisbon Investment Summit I went to a session called â€œWhat it means to be ambitious for founders in Europeâ€ by Oussama Ammar. Iâ€™ve written generally about the summit here.

Oussama spoke with passion and humour. Itâ€™s clear that he cares about encouraging would-be founders and confronting some of the cultural hurdles that exist in Europe. These are my notes from theÂ session:

  1. If you are serious about building something that matters then you have a great and exciting futureÂ ahead.
  2. You can never predict who will be successful and who will fail. There are a lot of dumb successful people and clever founders canÂ fail.
  3. Itâ€™s really important to learn how to leverage your time effectively. You can lose anything else and get it back but you can never recover the time youâ€™ve alreadyÂ spent.
  4. The only way to succeed is to tryÂ hard.
  5. Itâ€™s hard to do something thatÂ matters.
  6. In Europe you need to be more ambitious than average (measured against other countries) because the environment makes it harder to be an entrepreneur. (Attitudes to risk, comfort, security, expectations of failure.. are all unhelpful forÂ founders.)
  7. Itâ€™s not impossible, just harder. So be moreÂ ambitious.
  8. Everyone is replaceable, no-one isÂ unique.
  9. You can always lose money and replace it. There is so much money in theÂ world.
  10. Take a look at Crunchbase and see the failure rate for companies that raised $1m - $10m, it is the same rate for those that raisedÂ $10m+.
  11. If you lose money on a project you will learn things from that experience and you can leverage thatÂ learning
  12. â€¦ But you will never get back the time youÂ spent.
  13. Zombies are companies that make enough money to survive but not enough to provide joy to the people in the company - aim highÂ andâ€¦
  14. Starting a company is a big deal, like starting a marriage. Think hard about what you will be doing, what problem you are trying to solve, who you will be workingÂ with.
  15. In Europe there is not enough money to go around and this makes pitching hard. Silicon Valley doesnâ€™t have thisÂ problem.
  16. On average a startup in Europe will raise less than a startup in the USA.
  17. Europe is irrationally concerned about risk. USA is less concerned with risk and this is veryÂ helpful.
  18. So be pragmatic aboutÂ risk.
  19. Incorporate in London where the laws are good, even if you donâ€™t want to operate in the UK. It has a better designed system of corporate law. Estonia is alsoÂ good.

Best European city forÂ founders

London, Paris,Â Berlin..

  • There isnâ€™t a best city because none areÂ holistic
  • London has theÂ money
  • Paris has engineering and product development (and no-one outside Paris knows the productsÂ exist)
  • Berlin has automation and execution, execution andÂ scaling

â€¦You need to draw on all 3 of these cities, which when taken together can surpass SiliconÂ Valley.

Anecdotes

The founder of Slack lives in Vancouver with his wife and kids. He spends 1 day each week in California and everyone thinks Slack is Californian due to good marketing. Forget national pride, be pragmatic. Leverage theÂ internet.

The founders of Airbnb would fly from New York to California for 1 day each week. They were originally in California where AirBnB started, but decided that if they could make it work in New York then AirBnB would be a success, so they moved to New York and flew back for meetings , etc. If you ask Europeans to come to a meeting in London (which is not as far as California is from New York) people start complaining and deciding they canâ€™t beÂ bothered.

entry.title: The Lisbon InvestmentÂ Summit
entry.summary: The Lisbon investment Summit was full of Investors as well as Founders. The sessions were good enough but the real value was in the conversations.
entry.content:
I attended the Lisbon Investment Summit on June 6 and 7 as part of the Oula.la InsurTech startup team with John Sullivan. It was the first startup conference Iâ€™d been to and I arrived hoping to have some useful conversations and understand more about the Fintech and startup spaces in Europe. As usual I wanted to focus on tech, finance andÂ blockchains.

Who wasÂ there

As well as some outstanding sessions there was a high ratio of investors to startups. This made talking to VCs, bankers and M&A lawyers really easy. I was happy to meet a London-based and Fintech-focussed VC when I sat down to have lunch, and thanks to interrupting a session to ask blockchain related questions on Day 1, a banker struck up a conversation with me over breakfast the next day. I met a lot of people across many relevant roles, and once Iâ€™ve worked through my notes and my new collection of business cards I hope to have some great follow-upÂ meetings.

UsefulÂ Sessions

The most useful sessions for meÂ were:

  • â€œWhat it means to be ambitious for founders in Europeâ€ by Oussama Ammar from TheFamily

  • â€œUnderstanding Investmentâ€ by Boris Golden from PartechÂ Ventures

  • â€œBuilding successful businesses on blockchain technologiesâ€ a panel discussion moderated by Kevin Loaec, founder of the Chainsmiths blockchain consultancy, and including Mir Serena Liponi from BlockchainÂ Lab

The blockchain session was valuable because itâ€™s unusual to meet people who have been working in the blockchain space for several years. Iâ€™m always wary of being distracted by the hype and noise around developments in the blockchain space so I appreciated hearing some informed and level-headedÂ opinions.

PoliticalÂ Support

The opening session included a speech from the Mayor of Lisbon and the next day opened with a speech from the Secretary of Industry. Both speeches conveyed an open and progressive attitude to international cooperation aimed at promoting and supporting founders and startups in Portugal. The warm words were supported by practical measures including tax incentives and a state-backed scheme to match amounts contributed by private investors. It was really refreshing to hear a politician extol the virtues of multinational cooperation and bringing different cultures into Portugal. I wish Britain could do thisÂ too.

On the topic of Brexit, which inevitably arose due to Londonâ€™s present role as a centre of finance and innovation, it seems Europe is still expecting the UK to come to its senses, and cannot understand why itâ€™s destroying its goodwill and reputation soÂ thoroughly.

Overall

The two days in Lisbon were full of useful and energetic conversations and it was a great experience pitching Oula.la multiple times and talking about what weâ€™re trying to do and how blockchains are a part of that. The opportunities to meet founders and investors are invaluable for making informed decisions. Lisbon is a beautiful city which I found easy to get around and always felt safe in. Itâ€™s also refreshingly affordable!

entry.title: London Rent vs. LondonÂ Salaries
entry.summary: Living in London is only financially possible if you are either single or household income is more than Â£60k/year.
entry.content:
Living in London is expensive, everyone in the UK knows this. Everyone knows that this is mostly due to the price of property, which we all enjoy talkingÂ about.

Iâ€™ve lived here for 3 years now, and when my wife and I were both working we lived comfortably. Two incomes under one roof is just fine. Not as fine as in many other cities, but reasonable. Just over a year ago my first child was born, and now that my wifeâ€™s maternity pay has ended we are a single income household. This is notÂ fine.

Even though I earn almost Â£50k/year, and any salary increase will be taxed at 40%, I cannot cover essential day-to-day costs. Iâ€™m in the 40% tax bracket, and my basic monthly outgoings exceed my monthly take home pay by Â£400. If my employer wanted to pay me enough to cover essential costs, it would cost them approximately double the shortfall due to tax. None of this makesÂ sense.

Salaries and living expenses have become reallyÂ disconnected.

For most people the most obvious way to increase wealth is to buy property. Mortgage repayments are cheaper than rent, and the value of the property increases over time. Double win. But there is a big hurdle to overcome before this is possible - saving money for a deposit on a house is often impossible without external help (i.e. the â€œBank of Mum and Dadâ€), because so much of the money earnt must be spent on rentÂ first.

Itâ€™s a trap. Repayments on a mortgage are cheaper than paying rent, but you cannot save enough for a depositÂ because;

  1. so much of your salary goes to paying rent1,Â and
  2. the average cost of a flat in London is 500k2, which means a 5% deposit is Â£25k â€” which is a higher deposit than you would need anywhere else in the UK, despite being the place you are least able to accumulateÂ it.

What if my partner went back to work and we put our baby in childcare? Childcare is not cheap, and working would need to bring in more than the cost of childcare. This requires a higher than average salary from a graduate job, (which is the life stage when people might reasonably start having children), so unless both parents are unusually high earners that option isnt viableÂ either.

Living in London is only financially possible if you are either single or household income is more thanÂ Â£60k/year.
